#Text=Paris Charles de Gaulle Airport
#Text=Paris Charles de Gaulle Airport ( CDG ) is the main airport of Paris , one of the busiest hubs in Europe , largest airport in France and home of the national carrier , Air France .
#Text=It is located north of Paris and is sometimes referred to as Roissy Airport .
#Text=The airport is named after the General Charles de Gaulle , wartime leader of the Free French and later President of France .
#Text=It is owned by the Aéroports de Paris group together with Paris Orly Airport .
#Text=Understand
#Text=CDG is amongst the largest airports in the world not only in terms of traffic , but also surface area , and its multiple disjointed terminals and sheer size may be disorienting .

#Text=While connections to , from , and via CDG are often attractive , one needs to take extra care not to get lost , and plan in extra time to just cover the distances needed to get to or from the gate .
#Text=Terminals
#Text=CDG has three terminals .
#Text=The free CDGVal shuttle train runs between terminals , car parks and train stations .
#Text=Terminal 1 .
#Text=The original one , built in the 1970s to serve the intercontinental " jumbo jets " that had just debuted in service .

#Text=It is notable for its unusual layout and retrofuturistic brutalist design , with a round central section featuring underground travelator connections to seven " satellites " named 1T through 1Z ( not used at the airport but used on the guide to talk about the different satellites ) to which planes dock via jetways .
#Text=Nowadays it is used by Star Alliance carriers and some other non-allied airlines .
#Text=Terminal 2 .
#Text=The notoriously confusing gigantic one , consisting of interconnected sections named 2A through 2G .
#Text=Terminal 2G is a separate building from other " Terminals 2x " and is only reachable via navette/bus in 10-15 min ( bus leaves every 20 min ) so allow extra time if you travel to/from there .
#Text=Terminal 2 houses all Air France flights , as well as those of other SkyTeam carriers , with some other airlines ' gates spread over the many sections .
#Text=Notably , Easyjet uses terminal 2D .
#Text=Terminal 3 .
#Text=The low-cost terminal serving low-fare carriers , including Vueling , but not Easyjet , which has gates in 2D .
#Text=The CDGVal station shared with Roissypôle requires a walk from the CDGVal station to its entrance , and has limited facilities .
#Text=Gare Aéroport Charles de Gaulle 2 TGV
#Text=This is the TGV train station in the middle of the airport 's Terminal 2 ( between sections 2C/D and 2E/F of the Terminal ) , where both national and international TGV trains stop .
#Text=Both the RER B train and CDGVal stop here ( both stations shared with Terminal 2 ) .
#Text=Roissypôle
#Text=The area consisting of hotels and other services situated between the Northern side ( Terminal 1 and 3 ) and Southern side ( Terminal 2 ) of the airport .
#Text=It has a CDGVal stop shared with Terminal 3 , and also has the second of the 2 RER B stops , closer on the way to Paris .
#Text=Flights
#Text=Check with your airline before leaving for the airport .
#Text=Terminal 1
#Text=Most Star Alliance flights .
#Text=Terminal 2
#Text=Air France , Air Canada , easyJet , most Skyteam flights , and most OneWorld flights .
#Text=Terminal 3
#Text=Most low cost carrier flights .
#Text=Destinations
#Text=A list of destinations is available on Paris Aéroport 's website : https://www.parisaeroport.fr/en/passengers/flights/destinations/destinations-directory
#Text=By train to Paris
#Text=The RER train line " B " connects CDG airport to central Paris and is the fastest and most economical option for most travelers .
#Text=The airport has stations in T3 ( where you can take the free CDGVAL shuttle train to T1 ) and T2 .

#Text=Trains to Paris leave every 8 minutes and all stop at Gare du Nord ( TGVs to Lille , Eurostar trains to the UK and Thalys trains to Belgium and Holland ) , Châtelet-Les Halles , Saint-Michel Notre-Dame , Luxembourg , Port-Royal , Denfert-Rochereau and Cité Universitaire .
#Text=Adult tickets cost € 10.3 , and for children between 4-9 the fare is € 7 each .
#Text=You can also purchase daily pass for all trains inside Paris for zones 1 to 5 for € 17.6 , which makes it a better and cheaper option if you 're making a round trip .
#Text=Tickets are valid for connecting travel to any metro or RER station within Paris .
#Text=The train takes around 35 minutes to Gare du Nord and 45 minutes to Denfert-Rochereau , making this the fastest way to get to the city .

#Text=Tickets can be purchased either through green ( sometimes blue ) automated ticket vending machines ( " Billetterie Île-de-France " ) or through the ticket office serviced by transit authority personnel .

#Text=The automated ticket machines accept euro coins of € 2 , € 1 and 50 , 20 , 10 , 5 cent denominations and give change . ' Chip & PIN ' credit card ( typical in Europe and elsewhere ) payment is OK on these machines , but cards from the US ( or in general have only a magnetic strip or ' chip & signature ' ) , you most likely will not be able to use your card .
#Text=In the airport stations there are separate automated machines which change € 20 , € 10 and € 5 notes to € 2 and € 1 coins .
#Text=However , due to the high demand , the machines frequently run out of coins .
#Text=The currency exchanges explicitly state notes will not be changed for coins .
#Text=Because of these limitations , purchasing tickets from the ticket office may be your only option .
#Text=Although there are many counters , the queues can be very long .
#Text=Trains for Paris leave from platforms 11 and 12 .
#Text=Look for signs saying " RER B " or " All trains go to Paris " .
#Text=When using the ticket from and to the airport ( as with tickets for the RER commuter trains in general ) you have to use it to enter and to exit the quay areas .
#Text=Always keep the ticket handy as the SNCF officials sometimes check for tickets , and if you are without one you may be fined € 40 .

#Text=This means that after you put the ticket into the entry gate and are cleared to pass , you must retrieve the ticket from the machine and keep it with you until you leave the train system including any connections .

#Text=During off-peak hours and on the weekends , if you 're not in a hurry , avoid the trains from the airport heading to Saint Rémy lès Chevreuse : they will stop at all stations between the airport and Paris .
#Text=Instead , wait a few minutes for a train heading to Massy-Palaiseau , it will be non-stop between the airport and Paris Gare du Nord ( but wo n't overtake the omnibus train ) .

#Text=If you 're going to the airport , look on the information displays on the platforms : if the next train to Aéroport Charles de Gaulle stops at a dozen of stations , the next one should go to Mitry Claye ( do n't take that one ) , and then the following one will be non-stop from Paris Gare du Nord to the airport .
#Text=But remember , this is only during off-peak hours , as well as all day on the weekends .
